==Horror and science fiction==
Unlike silent-era sex and crime pictures, silent horror movies, despite being produced in the hundreds, were never a major concern for censors or civic leaders. When sound horror films were released however, they quickly caused controversy. Sound provided "atmospheric music and sound effects, creepy-voiced macabre dialogue and a liberal dose of blood-curdling screams" which intensified its effects on audiences, and consequently on moral crusaders.<ref name="Sm57">Smith, pg. 57.</ref><ref>Berenstein, pp. 2, 14.</ref> The Hays Code did not mention gruesomeness, and filmmakers took advantage of this oversight. However, state boards usually had no set guidelines and could object to any material they found indecent.<ref name="DH297">Doherty, pg. 297.</ref> Although films such as ''[[Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]'' and ''[[Freaks]]'' caused controversy when they were released, they had already been re-cut to comply with censors.<ref>Doherty, pg. 303.</ref>
[[File:Frankenstein's monster (Boris Karloff).jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Boris Karloff]] in ''[[Frankenstein (1931)|Frankenstein]]'' (1931). The monster's brutality, and the doctor's declaration that "[[Frankenstein (1931 film)#Pre-Code era scenes and censorship history|"Now I know what it feels like to be God!"]], shocked many moviegoers. By the time of ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'' (1935), the Code was in full effect.<ref>Gardner (1988), pg. 66.</ref><ref>Teresi, Dick. [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/13/books/are-you-mad-doctor.html?pagewanted=2 "Are You Mad, Doctor?"], ''The New York Times'', September 13, 1988; accessed November 24, 2010.</ref>]]
Comprising the nascent motion picture genres of [[Horror film|horror]] and [[science fiction]], the nightmare picture provoked individual psychological terror in its horror incarnations, while embodying group sociological terror in its science fiction manifestations. The two main types of pre-Code horror pictures were the single monster movie, and films where masses of hideous beasts rose up and attacked their putative betters. ''Frankenstein'' and ''Freaks'' exemplified both genres.<ref>Doherty, pp. 296, 299, 308.</ref>
The pre-Code horror cycle was motivated by financial necessity. Universal in particular buoyed itself with the production of horror hits such as ''[[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|Dracula]]'' (1931) and ''Frankenstein'', then followed those successes up with ''[[Murders in the Rue Morgue (1932 film)|Murders in the Rue Morgue]]'' (1932), ''[[The Mummy (1932 film)|The Mummy]]'' (1932), and ''[[The Old Dark House]]'' (1932). Other major studios responded with their own productions.<ref name="Sm57"/> Much like the crime film cycle, however, the intense boom of the horror cycle was ephemeral, and had fallen off at the box office by the end of the pre-Code era.<ref>Doherty, pg. 298.</ref>
While Joy declared ''Dracula'' "quite satisfactory from the standpoint of the Code" before it was released, and the film had little trouble reaching theaters, ''Frankenstein'' was a different story.<ref>Vieira, pp. 42–43.</ref> New York, Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts removed the scene where the monster unintentionally drowns a little girl and lines that referenced Dr. Frankenstein's God complex.<ref name="Vi43"/> [[Kansas]], in particular, objected to the film. The state's censor board requested the cutting of 32 scenes, which if removed, would have halved the length of the film.<ref name="DH297"/>
Paramount's ''[[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (1931 film)|Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde]]'' (1931) played to the Freudian theories popular with the audience of its time. [[Fredric March]] played the split-personality title character. Jekyll represented the composed [[super-ego]], and Hyde the lecherous [[Id, ego and super-ego|id]]. [[Miriam Hopkins]]'s coquettish bar singer, Ivy Pierson, sexually teases Jekyll early in the film by displaying parts of her legs and bosom.<ref name="DH305">Doherty, pg. 305.</ref> Joy felt the scene had been "dragged in simply to titillate the audience."<ref name="Vi43">Vieira, pg. 43.</ref> Hyde coerces her with the threat of violence into becoming his paramour and beats her when she attempts to stop seeing him. She is contrasted with his wholesome fiancée Muriel ([[Rose Hobart]]), whose chaste nature dissatisfies March's baser alter ego.<ref>[http://movies.tvguide.com/dr-jekyll-mr-hyde/review/113132 Review: ''Dr. Jekyll And Mr. Hyde''], tvguide.com; accessed November 24, 2010.</ref> The film is considered the "most honored of the Pre-Code horror films."<ref>Doherty, pp. 303–304.</ref> Many of the graphic scenes between Hyde and Ivy were cut by local censors because of their suggestiveness.<ref>Vieira, pg. 49.</ref> Sex was intimately tied to horror in many pre-Code horror movies. In ''Murders in the Rue Morgue'', an adaptation of [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s [[The Murders in the Rue Morgue|classic tale]] which has little in common with the source material, [[Bela Lugosi]] plays a mad scientist who tortures and kills women, trying to mix human blood with ape blood during his experiments. His prized experiment, an intelligent ape named Erik, breaks into a woman's second-floor apartment window and rapes her.<ref>Doherty, pp. 305–307.</ref>
[[File:Rue Morgue.JPG|thumb|right|In ''[[Murders in the Rue Morgue (1932 film)|Murders in the Rue Morgue]]'' (1932), the shadow of the ape's hand appears over head of Camille ([[Sidney Fox]]) as it enters her room. What follows has been dubbed "interspecies miscegenation" by film historian Thomas Doherty.<ref name="DH305"/>]]
In ''Freaks'', director [[Tod Browning]] of ''Dracula'' fame helms a picture that depicts a traveling circus populated by a group of deformed carnival freaks. Browning populated the movie with actual carnival sideshow performers including "midgets, dwarfs, hermaphrodites, Siamese twins, and, most awful, the armless and legless man billed as the 'living torso'".<ref name="DH313">Doherty, pg. 313.</ref> There is also a group of Pinheads, who are depicted as fortunate in that they are not mentally capable enough to understand that they disgust people.<ref name="DH313"/> But the truly unsavory characters here are the villains, the circus strongman Hercules and the beautiful high-wire artist Cleopatra, who intends to marry and poison Hans, the midget heir who is enamored of her. At a dinner celebrating their union, one of the freaks dances on the table as they chant "gooble-gobble, gobble, gobble, one of us, one of us, we accept her, we accept her." Disgusted, Cleopatra insults Hans and makes out with Hercules in front of him. When the freaks discover her plot, they exact revenge by mutilating Cleopatra into a freak.<ref>Doherty, pp. 313–318.</ref> Although circus freaks were common in the early 1930s, the film was their first depiction on screen.<ref name="DH313" /> Browning took care to linger over shots of the deformed, disabled performers with long takes of them including one of the "living torso" lighting a match and then a cigarette with his mouth. The film was accompanied by a sensational marketing campaign that asked sexual questions such as "Do the Siamese Twins make love?", "What sex is the half-man half-woman?", and "Can a full grown woman truly love a midget?"<ref>Doherty, pp. 315–317.</ref> Surprisingly, given its reaction to ''Frankenstein'', the state of [[Kansas]] objected to nothing in ''Freaks''.<ref>Butters, pg. 206.</ref> However, other states, such as Georgia, were repulsed by the film and it was not shown in many locales.<ref>Doherty, pp. 317–18.</ref> The film later became a cult classic spurred by [[midnight movie]] showings,<ref>Phipps, Keith. [http://www.avclub.com/articles/freaks,11321 Review of the film ''Freaks'' profile], avclub.com, August 16, 2004; accessed November 26, 2010.</ref> but it was a box-office bomb in its original release.<ref>Doherty, pg. 318.</ref>
In ''[[Island of Lost Souls (1932 film)|Island of Lost Souls]]'' (1932), an adaptation of [[H. G. Wells]]' science-fiction novel, ''[[The Island of Doctor Moreau]]'', [[Charles Laughton]] plays yet another mad scientist with a God complex.<ref>Vieira, pg. 147.</ref> As Moreau, Laughton creates a mad scientist's island paradise, an unmonitored haven where he is free to create a race of man-beasts and Lota, a beast-woman he wants to mate with a normal human male. A castaway lands on his island, providing him an opportunity to see how far his science experiment, the barely clothed, attractive Lota, has come. The castaway discovers Moreau [[vivisection|vivisecting]] one of the beast-men and attempts to leave the island. He runs into the camp of the man-beasts and Moreau beats them back with a whip. The film ends with Lota dead, the castaway rescued, and the man-beasts chanting, "Are we not men?" as they attack and then vivisect Moreau.<ref>Doherty, pp. 308–311.</ref> The film has been described as "a rich man's ''Freaks''" due to its esteemed source material.<ref name="Vi132">Vieira, p. 132.</ref> Wells, however, despised the movie for its lurid excesses. It was rejected by 14 local censor boards in the United States, and considered "against nature" in Great Britain, where it was banned until 1958.<ref name="Vi132" /><ref>Hanke, Ken. [http://www.mountainx.com/movies/review/island_of_lost_souls_white_zombie REVIEW: ''Island of Lost Souls''/''White Zombie''], ''Mountain Xpress'', August 24, 2010; accessed November 26, 2010.</ref>
==Exotic adventure films== [[File:Bird of Paradise (1932) 2.jpg|thumb|left|<center>[[Dolores del Río]] dances almost [[Toplessness|topless]] in ''[[Bird of Paradise (1932 film)|Bird of Paradise]]'' (1932).</center>]]
Pre-Code films contained a continual, recurring theme of white racism.<ref name="DH254">Doherty, pg. 254.</ref> In the early 1930s, the studios filmed a series of pictures that aimed to provide viewers a sense of the exotic, an exploration of the unknown and the forbidden. These pictures often imbued themselves with the allure of interracial sex according to pre-Code historian Thomas Doherty. "At the psychic core of the genre is the shiver of sexual attraction, the threat and promise of miscegenation."<ref name="DH254"/> Films such as ''[[Africa Speaks]]'' were directly marketed by referencing interracial sex; moviegoers received small packets labeled "Secrets" which contained pictures of naked black women.<ref name="DH255">Doherty, pg. 255.</ref> As portrayals of historic conditions, these movies are of little educational value, but as artifacts that show Hollywood's attitude towards race and foreign cultures they are enlightening.<ref name="DH254"/> The central point of interest in ''[[The Blonde Captive]]'' (1931), a film which depicted a blonde woman abducted by a savage tribe of Aboriginal Australians, was not that she was kidnapped, but that she enjoys living among the tribe.<ref name="DH255"/> The lack of black characters in films highlights their status in [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow America]].<ref>Doherty, pp. 255–256.</ref>
In ''[[Bird of Paradise (1932 film)|Bird of Paradise]]'', a white American man ([[Joel McCrea]]) enjoys a torrid affair with a Polynesian princess ([[Dolores del Río]]). The film created a scandal when released due to a scene featuring del Río [[Skinny dipping|swimming naked]].<ref>[http://www.filmsite.org/sexinfilms5.html Sex in Cinema], AMC filmsite</ref> [[Orson Welles]] said del Río represented the highest erotic ideal with her performance in the film.<ref>[http://dawnsdeloresdelrio.blogspot.com/2010/05/bird-of-paradise1932-pre-code.html ''Bird of Paradise'' (1932 film) review], dawnsdeloresdelrio.blogspot.com; accessed June 23, 2014.</ref>
The white protagonist in ''[[Tarzan the Ape Man (1932 film)|Tarzan, the Ape Man]]'' (1932) is the "King of the [African] Jungle". Tarzan ([[Johnny Weissmuller]]) is a monosyllabic half-naked jungle creature whose attractiveness is derived from his physical prowess; throughout the movie, he saves Jane ([[Maureen O'Sullivan]]) from danger and she swoons in his arms.<ref>Doherty, p. 257.<br/>Hall, Mourdant. [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=1&res=9803E3DA163EE633A2575BC2A9659C946394D6CF&partner=Rotten%20Tomatoes Tarzan, the Ape Man (1932)], ''The New York Times'', February 28, 1932, accessed December 15, 2010.</ref> When Jane's father warns her "[h]e's not like us", she responds, "[h]e's white" as evidence to the contrary.<ref name="Tarz">[[W. S. Van Dyke|Van Dyke, W.S.]] ''Tarzan, the Ape Man'' (1932) Hollywood: MGM</ref> In the racy 1934 sequel, ''[[Tarzan and His Mate]]'' (the last word meaning both a status and a biological function<ref>Doherty, pg. 259.</ref>), men come from the U.S. with fancy gowns and other accoutrements to woo and clothe the bra-less, barely clothed Jane, again played by O'Sullivan, hoping to lure her away from the savage Tarzan.<ref>[http://www.film4.com/reviews/1934/tarzan-and-his-mate ''Tarzan and His Mate'' reviews], film4.com, accessed December 15, 2010</ref> He detests the fancier clothing and tears it off. The film included a skinny-dipping scene with extensive nudity with a body double standing in for O'Sullivan.<ref name="Tarz2">[[Cedric Gibbons|Gibbons, Cedric]]. ''Tarzan and His Mate'' (1934). Hollywood: MGM<br />[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117795460?refcatid=31 Tarzan and His Mate], ''Variety'', December 31, 1933, accessed December 15, 2010.<br/>Doherty, pg. 260.</ref> Breen, then head of the SRC, objected to the scene, and MGM, the movie's producer, decided to take their case to the appeals review board. The board consisted of the heads of Fox, RKO, and Universal. After watching the scene "several times", the board sided with Breen and the MPPDA, and the scene was removed, but MGM still allowed some uncut trailers and a few reels to stay in circulation.<ref>Doherty, pp. 260–261.<br/>Vieira, pp. 179–80.</ref> MGM marketed the film primarily towards women using taglines such as:<ref>Doherty, pg. 262.</ref>
{{quote|<poem> Girls! Would you live like Eve if you found the right Adam? Modern marriages could learn plenty from this drama of primitive jungle mating! If all marriages were based on the primitive mating instinct, it would be a better world.</poem>}}
[[File:Tarzan and His Mate (1934) trailer 1.jpg|thumb|right|<center>''[[Tarzan and His Mate]]'' (1934)</center>]]
Ethnic characters were portrayed against stereotype in ''[[Massacre (1934 film)|Massacre]]'' (1934). The protagonist ([[Richard Barthelmess]]) is a Native American who performs in a [[Wild West Shows|Wild West Show]] in full Indian garb, but then slips into a suit and speaks in American slang once the show is over.<ref>Doherty, pg. 263.</ref> He has a black butler who is atypically intelligent; his character merely plays dumb by slipping into a stereotypical slow-witted "negro" character when it suits him, rather than being genuinely unintelligent.<ref>Doherty, pg. 266.</ref>
Films such as ''[[The Mask of Fu Manchu]]'' (1932), ''[[Shanghai Express (film)|Shanghai Express]]'' (1932) and ''[[The Bitter Tea of General Yen]]'' (1933), explored the exoticism of the Far East — by using white actors, not Asians, in the lead roles. The white actors frequently looked absurd in [[Portrayal of East Asians in Hollywood|yellow-face makeup]] next to genuine Asians, so the studios would cast all the Asian parts white.<ref>Doherty, pg. 268.</ref> Generally, "[[Yellow Peril]]" stereotypes dominated the portrayal of Asian characters, who were almost always villains.<ref name="Yunte, pg. 144">Yunte, pg. 144</ref> The American scholar Huang Yunte wrote that the character of Charlie Chan, a Chinese-American detective aided by his bumbling, Americanized "Number One Son" were virtually the only positive examples of Asian characters in Hollywood in this period.<ref name="Yunte, pg. 144"/> The actress [[Anna May Wong]] complained in a 1933 interview about the prevalence of "Yellow Peril" stereotypes in Hollywood saying: "Why is it that the screen Chinese is always the villain? And so crude a villain – murderous, treacherous, a snake in the grass! We are not like that. How could we be, with a civilization that is so many times older than the West?"<ref>Lim 2005, p. 58.</ref>
In ''Fu Manchu'', Boris Karloff plays the evil Chinese mad scientist and gangster Dr. Fu Manchu, who wants to find the sword and mask of [[Genghis Khan]], which will give him the power to control the "countless hordes" of Asians, and lead them into battle against the West.<ref name="fu"/> Fu is a sexual deviant who engages in ritual torture and has occult powers.<ref>Doherty, pp. 269–270.</ref> Several times, the film seems to suggest Fu is engaged in an incestuous relationship with his equally evil daughter Fah Lo See ([[Myrna Loy]]), which plays up a central theme of the "Yellow Peril" fears, the alleged abnormal sexuality of Asians.<ref name="Yunte, pg. 144"/> In a scene cut from the film due to its depiction of miscegenation, the film shows Fu's depraved daughter violating one of the chaste good characters.<ref>Vieira, pg. 88.</ref> Fu is eventually conquered, but not before he temporarily lays his hand on the sword and proclaims to a vast Pan-Asian army made up of Asians and Muslims: "Would you have maidens like this [referring to [[Karen Morley]]] for your wives? Then conquer and breed! Kill the white man and take his women!"<ref name="fu">[[Charles Brabin|Brabin, Charles]]. ''The Mask of Fu Manchu'' (1932). United States: MGM.</ref>
[[File:Marlene Dietrich in Shanghai Express (1932) by Don English.png|thumb|upright|left|<center>[[Marlene Dietrich]] in<br>''[[Shanghai Express (film)|Shanghai Express]]'' (1932)</center>]]''
The Chinese warlord General Henry Chang ([[Warner Oland]]) in the 1932 film [[Shanghai Express (film)|''Shanghai Express'']], who is presented as being not only as [[Eurasian (mixed ancestry)|Eurasian]], but as having a menacing asexuality that places him outside of the conventionally defined world of Western sexuality and racial order, making him as dangerous to the Western characters who he has taken hostage as much as the fact that he is a vicious warlord.<ref name="Marchetti pg 64">Marchetti pg 64</ref> Though Chang is Eurasian, he takes pride in his Chinese heritage while rejecting his American heritage, which confirms his Eastern identity.<ref name="Marchetti pg 64"/> War-torn China, circa 1931 is presented as a "hell", which a diverse group of Westerners must travel through on a nightmarish train trip from Beijing to [[Shanghai]], which takes a turn for the worse when the train is hijacked by Chang and his men.<ref>Marchetti pg 61</ref> The film strongly hints that Chang is bisexual, who not only wants to rape the heroine Shanghai Lily ([[Marlene Dietrich]]), but also the hero Captain Donald "Doc" Harvey ([[Clive Brook]]).<ref name="Marchetti pg 64"/> When the German opium smuggler Erich Baum ([[Gustav von Seyffertitz]]) insults Chang, the result is a scene where the warlord commits a symbolic rape, as the sadistic Chang clearly takes sexual pleasure in branding Baum with a red-hot poker.<ref>Marchetti pg. 64-65.</ref> After he is branded (the symbol of slavery), the once proud Baum becomes notably cowed and submissive towards Chang who in a certain sense now "owns" him, which reflected the ultimate Yellow Peril fear of Westerners becoming the slaves of the East and its perverted sexuality.<ref>Marchetti pg 65</ref> Later on, Chang does actually rape Hui Fei ([[Anna May Wong]]).<ref name="Marchetti pg. 65">Marchetti pg. 65.</ref> Gina Marchetti suggests that Chang's desire to blind Harvey is not only meant literally, but is also a metaphor for castration, which even under the more permissive Production code in effect in 1932 would have been a taboo subject.<ref>Marchetti pg 65.</ref> In a marked contrast to Chang's twisted sexuality and his "almost effeminate polish", the British Army Captain Harvey is a resolutely heterosexual, ruggedly tough soldier with a deep romantic streak who more than amply proved his manliness in the trenches of World War I, presenting a model of Western masculinity and strength.<ref>Marchetti 64-65.</ref>
At several times, the film hints that Shanghai Lily and Hui Fei are more than best friends, and are in fact engaged in a lesbian relationship, so when the film ends with Lily choosing Harvey as her lover, this serves as a testament to his manly Western sex appeal, which "redeems" her from her life as a prostitute.<ref>Marchetti pg. 60-65</ref> At the same time that ''Shanghai Express'' embraces Yellow Peril stereotypes through the character of Chang, it also to some extent undermines them through the character of Hui, who is shown crying inconsolably after being raped by Chang, which gives her a certain humanity and allows the audience to sympathize with her.<ref name="Marchetti pg. 65"/> Hui is a courtesan who is looked down upon by all Western characters except for her best friend Lily on the account of her race and profession, but she is shown as possessing dignity and a willingness to stand up for herself.<ref>Chan pg. 232-234</ref> Several scenes seemed to suggest that Shanghai Lily and Hui are more attracted to one another then either are to Captain Harvey as the two women exchange longing glances more than once, through this may be suggesting Hui's sexuality is not quite normal (most people in 1932 would considered bi-sexuality to be unnatural).<ref>Chan pg. 232 & 236</ref> At one point, Hui wears a tight cheongsam dress, which clearly reveal her erect nipples, which definitely captures Lily's interest .<ref>Chan pg. 236</ref> The same criticism might be applied to Lily, but the film ends with Lily embracing heterosexual love by kissing Harvey while Hui walks off into the distance alone, sadder as a result of losing her best friend to Harvey and because she was raped, but otherwise unchanged.<ref>Chan pg. 236-237</ref> Finally, it is Hui who saves Harvey in the climax from being blinded/raped/castrated at the hands of Chang by killing Chang; Hui explains the killing as her way of regaining the self-respect that Chang had taken away from her.<ref>Chan pg. 232 & 236-237</ref>
[[Frank Capra]]'s ''The Bitter Tea of General Yen'' was not quite the same type of film: Stanwyck plays a missionary who goes to civil-war-torn China and meets the titular general (played by [[Nils Asther]]) after his car kills the driver of her [[Pulled rickshaw|rickshaw]]. When she is knocked unconscious in a riot, he takes her out of the rabble and onto a train car. She has lurid, horror-themed, symbolic dreams about the General, in which she is both titillated and repulsed by him. The film breaks precedent by developing into an interracial love story, but his army ends in ruins. Yen kills himself at the film's conclusion—by drinking poisoned tea—rather than be captured and killed.<ref>Doherty, pp. 270–274.</ref> Capra adored the script and disregarded the risk of making a film that broke California's (and 29 other states') laws concerning the portrayal of miscegenation. Cinematographer [[Joseph Walker (cinematographer)|Joseph Walker]] tested a new technique he created, which he dubbed "Variable Diffusion", in filming the picture. This rendered the entire picture in very [[soft focus]].<ref name="Vi118"/>
==Newsreels and documentaries== {{Main|Newsreel}}
From 1904 until 1967, when television finally killed them off, newsreels preceded films. In the early sound-film era, they lasted around eight minutes and featured highlights and clips of the world's biggest stories. Updated twice a week by the five major studios, they became a highly profitable enterprise: in 1933, newsreels had a total box office take of almost $19.5 million against an outlay of under $10 million.<ref>Doherty, pp. 197, 212.</ref> The sound-film era created the narrator; among the first was [[Graham McNamee]], who provided voiceover during the clips, often delivering hackneyed jokes while delineating the on-screen action.<ref>Doherty, pp. 174–175, 198.</ref> Sound newsreel interviews and monologues featured famous subjects unaccustomed to the new medium. These clips changed public perception of important historical figures depending on their elocution, the sound of their previously unheard voices, and their composure in front of the camera.<ref>Doherty, pp. 200–202.</ref> Around 12 "newsreel theaters" were soon created around the United States, the most successful being the Embassy Newsreel Theater on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]]. The Embassy was a 578-seat facility that presented fourteen 45–50 minute programs a day, running from 10 in the morning until midnight.<ref>Doherty, pg. 200.</ref> It was noted for its discerning, intellectual audience, many of whom did not attend motion-picture theaters.<ref>Doherty, pg. 212.</ref>
[[File:All Quiet on the Western Front lobby card.jpg|thumb|right|''[[All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film)|All Quiet on the Western Front]]'' (1930). one of the first American films to portray the horrors of [[World War I]], received great praise from the public for its humanitarian, anti-war message.]]
The most gripping news story of the pre-Code era was the [[Lindbergh kidnapping|kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby]] on the evening of 1 March 1932.<ref name="Gill"/> As the child was already enormously famous before the kidnapping, the event created a media circus, with news coverage more intense than anything since World War I. Newsreels featuring family photos of the child (the first time private pictures had been "conscripted for public service"<ref>Doherty, pp. 218–219.</ref>) asked spectators to report any sight of him. On May 12, 1932, the child's body was found less than five miles from the Lindbergh home.<ref name="Gill">Gill, Barbara. [http://www.nj.com/lindbergh/hunterdon/index.ssf?/lindbergh/stories/demcovr.html "Lindbergh kidnapping rocked the world 50 years ago"], ''[[The Hunterdon County Democrat]]'', 1981, accessed October 29, 2010</ref><ref name="DH220">Doherty, p. 220.</ref> Although newsreels covered the most important topics of the day, they also presented [[Human interest story|human-interest stories]] (such as the immensely popular coverage of the [[Dionne quintuplets]]<ref name="DH220"/>) and entertainment news, at times in greater detail than more pressing political and social matters.<ref>Doherty, pg. 199.</ref>
Some of the images' impact belies their historical accuracy; nearly all ceremonies and public events that were filmed for newsreels in the early sound era were staged, and in some cases even reenacted. For instance: when FDR signed an important bill, a member of his cabinet was called away before the staged reenactment began, so the film shows him absent at the time of the signing, although he had been present.<ref>Doherty, pp. 203–204.</ref> The newsreels of FDR were staged to hide his hobbled gait caused by polio.<ref name="DH7785">Doherty, pp. 81–82.</ref> Caught between the desire to present accurate hard-hitting news stories and the need to keep an audience in the mood for the upcoming entertainment, newsreels often soft-pedaled the difficulties Americans faced during the early years of the Great Depression.<ref>Doherty, pp. 208, 213–215.</ref> FDR in particular received favorable treatment from Hollywood, with all five of the major studios producing pro-FDR shorts by late 1933. These shorts featured some of the studios' lesser contract talent extolling the virtues of FDR created government and social programs.<ref>Doherty, pg. 84.</ref> Roosevelt himself was a natural before the camera. The newsreels were instrumental to the success of his initial campaign, and his enduring popularity while in office.<ref name="DH7785"/> He was described by ''Variety'' as the "Barrymore of the Capital".<ref name="DH79"/>
Taking advantage of the existence of 30 years of newsreels archives were filmmakers who made early sound era documentaries. World War I was a popular topic of these pictures and spawned the following documentaries; ''[[Albert Leroy Rule#Filmography|The Big Drive]]'' (1933), ''World in Revolt'' (1933), ''This is America'' (1933), and ''Hell's Holiday'' (1933).<ref>Doherty, pp. 204–205.</ref> The most prescient{{clarify|date=February 2016|reason=Prescient in what sense?}} pre-Code World War I documentary was aptly called ''The First World War'' (1934) and was the most critically and commercially successful documentary of the era.
Filmmakers also made feature-length documentaries that covered the dark recesses of the globe, including the [[Amazon rainforest]], [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American settlements]], the [[Pacific islands]], and everywhere in between. Taking advantage of audiences' voyeuristic impulses, aided by the allowance of nudity in tribal documentaries, the filming of lands untouched by modernity, and the presentation of locales never before filmed, these movies placated Depression era American audiences by showing them lifestyles more difficult than their own.<ref>Doherty, pp. 223, 225–227.</ref> Also captured were Arctic expeditions in films such ''90° South'' and ''[[With Byrd at the South Pole]]'', and [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] in the [[safari]] films of [[Martin and Osa Johnson]], among others.<ref>Doherty, pp. 227–228, 246.</ref>
Some exploitation style documentaries purported to show actual events but were instead staged, elaborate ruses. The most prominent of which was ''[[Ingagi]]'' (1931), a film which claimed to show a ritual where African women were given over to gorillas as sex slaves, but instead was mostly filmed in Los Angeles using local blacks in place of natives.<ref>Doherty, pp. 236, 241.</ref> [[Douglas Fairbanks]] mocked the phoniness of many pre-Code documentaries in his parody ''[[Around the World in 80 Minutes with Douglas Fairbanks]]'', in one scene of which he filmed himself wrestling a stuffed tiger doll, then a tiger-skin rug.<ref>Doherty, pg. 243.</ref> Opposing these films was the [[travelogue (films)|travelogue]] which was shown before features and served as a short saccharine form of cinematic tourism.<ref name="DH222">Doherty, pg. 222.</ref>
==Beginning of Code era (July 1, 1934)== ===Pre-code: "Don'ts" and "Be Carefuls", as proposed in 1927===
The Code enumerated a number of key points known as the "Don'ts" and "Be Carefuls":<ref name="Hollywood">Lewis (2000), [https://books.google.com/books?id=4OBepfVJOeEC&pg=PA301 pp. 301–02]</ref> {{quote|Resolved, That those things which are included in the following list shall not appear in pictures produced by the members of this Association, irrespective of the manner in which they are treated:
{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * Pointed profanity – by either title or lip – this includes the words "God," "Lord," "Jesus," "Christ" (unless they be used reverently in connection with proper religious ceremonies), "hell," "damn," "Gawd," and every other profane and vulgar expression however it may be spelled; * Any licentious or suggestive nudity – in fact or in silhouette; and any lecherous or licentious notice thereof by other characters in the picture; * The illegal traffic in drugs; * Any inference of sex perversion; * [[Sexual slavery#White slavery|White slavery]]; * [[Miscegenation]] (sex relationships between the white and black races); * [[sexual health|Sex hygiene]] and venereal diseases; * Scenes of actual childbirth – in fact or in silhouette; * Children's sex organs; * Ridicule of the clergy; * Willful offense to any nation, race or creed; }}
And be it further resolved, That special care be exercised in the manner in which the following subjects are treated, to the end that vulgarity and suggestiveness may be eliminated and that good taste may be emphasized: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * The use of the flag; * International relations (avoiding picturizing in an unfavorable light another country's religion, history, institutions, prominent people, and citizenry); * Arson; * The use of firearms; * Theft, robbery, safe-cracking, and dynamiting of trains, mines, buildings, etc. (having in mind the effect which a too-detailed description of these may have upon the [[moron (psychology)|moron]]); * Brutality and possible gruesomeness; * Technique of committing murder by whatever method; * Methods of smuggling; * [[Third degree (interrogation)|Third-degree]] methods; * Actual hangings or electrocutions as legal punishment for crime; * Sympathy for criminals; * Attitude toward public characters and institutions; * [[Sedition]]; * Apparent cruelty to children and animals; * Branding of people or animals; * The sale of women, or of a woman selling her virtue; * Rape or attempted rape; * [[wedding night|First-night]] scenes; * Man and woman in bed together; * Deliberate seduction of girls; * The institution of marriage; * Surgical operations; * The use of drugs; * Titles or scenes having to do with law enforcement or law-enforcing officers; * Excessive or lustful kissing, particularly when one character or the other is a "[[criminal|heavy]]".}} }}
Pre-Code films began to draw the ire of various religious groups, some Protestant but mostly a contingent of Roman Catholic crusaders.<ref>LaSalle (2002), p. xii.</ref> [[Amleto Cicognani|Amleto Giovanni Cicognani]], apostolic delegate to the [[Catholic Church]] in the United States, called upon Roman Catholics in the United States to unite against the surging immorality of films. As a result, in 1933 the Catholic Legion of Decency, headed by the Reverend [[John T. McNicholas]] (later renamed the [[National Legion of Decency]]), was established to control and enforce decency standards and boycott films they deemed offensive.<ref>Doherty, pp. 320–321.</ref><ref name="TM">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,762190-1,00.html Religion: Legion of Decency], ''TIME'', June 11, 1934; accessed October 21, 2010.</ref> They created a rating system for films that started at "harmless" and ended at "condemned", with the latter denoting a film that was a sin to watch.<ref>Jowett, Jarvie, and Fuller, p. 93.</ref>
{{quote|I wish to join the Legion of Decency, which condemns vile and unwholesome moving pictures. I unite with all who protest against them as a grave menace to youth, to home life, to country and to religion. I condemn absolutely those salacious motion pictures which, with other degrading agencies, are corrupting public morals and promoting a sex mania in our land… Considering these evils, I hereby promise to remain away from all motion pictures except those which do not offend decency and Christian morality.|Catholic Legion of Decency Pledge<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/features/deep-focus/pre-code-hollywood|title=Pre-Code: Hollywood before the censors|work=British Film Institute|accessdate=October 30, 2015}}</ref>}}
The Legion spurred several million Roman Catholics across the U.S. to sign up for the boycott, allowing local religious leaders to determine which films to protest.<ref name="TM"/><ref name="Bl149">Black, pg. 149.</ref> Conservative Protestants tended to support much of the crackdown, particularly in the South, where anything relating to the state of race relations or miscegenation could not be portrayed. Although the Central Conference of American Rabbis joined in the protest, it was an uneasy alliance given the heavy presence of Jewish studio executives and producers, which, it was felt, had inspired at least some of the vitriol from the Catholic groups.<ref name="DH322"/>
Hays opposed direct censorship, considering it "Un-American". He had stated that although there were some tasteless films in his estimation, working with filmmakers was better than direct oversight, and that, overall, films were not harmful to children. Hays blamed some of the more prurient films on the difficult economic times which exerted "tremendous commercial pressure" on the studios more than a flouting of the code.<ref name="Bl150"/> Catholic groups became enraged with Hays and as early as July 1934 were demanding that he resign from his position, which he did not, although his influence waned and Breen took control, with Hays becoming a functionary.<ref>United Press. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hUwbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nEsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5627,4683275&dq=will-hays&hl=en "Movie Critic asks Film Czar to Quit"], ''[[The Pittsburgh Press]]'', July 7, 1934; accessed October 21, 2010.</ref><ref>Associated Press. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QQkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Jf0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=5087,263676&dq=will-hays&hl=en "Church Critics of Movies Call for Ousting of Will Hays"], ''[[Gettysburg Times]]'', July 10, 1934; accessed October 21, 2010.</ref>
[[File:MPPDA Seal.JPG|thumb|left|The PCA seal of approval in the 1930s. The Seal appeared before every picture approved by the MPPDA.]]
The [[The Payne Fund|Payne Study and Experiment Fund]] was created in 1927 by [[Frances Payne Bolton]] to support a study of the influence of fiction on children.<ref>Jowett, Jarvie, and Fuller, p. xvi.</ref> The [[Payne Fund Studies]], a series of eight<ref>See Jowett, Jarvie and Fuller, pg. 92. Frequently this number is mistakenly given as nine; nine were announced, but only eight were ever released.</ref> books published from 1933 to 1935 which detailed five (5) years of research aimed specifically at the cinema's effects on children, were also gaining publicity at this time, and became a great concern to Hays.<ref name="Bl150">Black, pg. 150.</ref><ref name="Jc107">Jacobs, pg. 107.</ref><ref>Massey, pg. 75.</ref> Hays had said certain pictures might alter "... that sacred thing, the mind of a child … that clean, virgin thing, that unmarked state" and have "the same responsibility, the same care about the thing put on it that the best clergyman or the most inspired teacher would have."<ref>Lewis, pg. 133.</ref> Despite its initial reception, the main findings of the study were largely innocuous. It found that cinema's effect on individuals varied with age and social position, and that pictures reinforced audiences' existing beliefs.<ref name="MS29">Massey, pg. 29.</ref><ref>Jowett, Jarvie, and Fuller, p. 5.</ref> The Motion Picture Research Council (MPRC, led by honorary vice president [[Sara Delano Roosevelt]] (mother of President Franklin D. Roosevelt),<ref>Doherty, p. 323.</ref> and executive director the Rev. William H. Short<ref>Saettler, pg. 229.</ref>) which funded the study, was not pleased. An "alarmist summary" of the study's results written by [[Henry James Forman]] appeared in ''[[McCall's]]'', a leading women's magazine of the time, and Forman's book, ''[[Our Movie Made Children]]'', which became a best-seller, publicized the Payne Fund's results, emphasizing its more negative aspects.<ref name="DH322">Doherty, pg. 322.</ref><ref>Massey, pp. 29–30.<br>*Jowett, Jarvie, and Fuller, pp. 94–95.</ref>
The social environment created by the publicity of the Payne Fund Studies and religious protests reached such a fever pitch that a member of the Hays Office described it as a "state of war".<ref name="Ja106" /> However, newspapers including ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' ([[Cleveland]]), ''[[New Orleans Times Picayune]]'', ''[[Chicago Daily News]]'', ''[[Atlanta Journal]]'', ''[[Saint Paul Dispatch]]'', the Philadelphia [[The Philadelphia Record|''Record'']] and ''[[Public Ledger (Philadelphia)|''Public Ledger]]'', the ''[[Boston American]]'' and New York's ''[[New York Daily News|Daily News]]'', ''[[New York Daily Mirror|Daily Mirror]]'', and ''[[New York Post|Evening Post]]'' all lambasted the studies.<ref>Black, pg. 154.</ref> When discussing the Supreme Court's 1915 decision, film historian Gregory Black argues that the efforts of reformers might have been lessened had "filmmakers been willing to produce films for specialized audiences (adults only, family, no children) … but the movers and shakers of the industry wanted or needed the largest possible market."<ref>Black, pg. 18.</ref> The most provocative pictures were the most profitable, with the 25% of the motion picture industry's output that was the most sensational supporting the cleaner 75%.<ref>[[Richard Corliss]] essay reprinted in Schatz, pg. 144.</ref>
By 1932, there was an increasing movement for government control.<ref>Butters Jr, p. 191.</ref> By mid-1934 when Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia called for a Catholic boycott of all films, and [[Raymond Joseph Cannon|Raymond Cannon]] was privately preparing a congressional bill supported by both Democrats and Republicans which would introduce Government oversight, the studios decided they had had enough.<ref>Doherty, pp. 321, 324–325. * Corliss essay in Schatz, pg. 149.</ref> They re-organized the enforcement procedures giving Hays and the recently appointed [[Joseph Breen|Joseph I. Breen]], a devout Roman Catholic, head of the new [[Production Code Administration]] (PCA), greater control over censorship.<ref>Doherty, pp. 8, 9.</ref> The studios agreed to disband their appeals committee and to impose a $25,000 fine for producing, distributing, or exhibiting any film without PCA approval.<ref name="ah"/> Hays had originally hired Breen, who had worked in public relations, in 1930 to handle Production Code publicity, and the latter was popular among Catholics.<ref>Butters Jr., pg. 190.<br/>* Jeff & Simmmons, pg. 55.<br/>* Ross, pg. 270.</ref> Joy began working solely for [[Fox Studios]], and Wingate had been bypassed in favor of Breen in December 1933.<ref>Jacobs, pg. 109.</ref><ref>Smith, pg. 60.</ref> Hays became a functionary, while Breen handled the business of censoring films.<ref>LaSalle (1999), pg. 192.</ref>
Breen initially had anti-Semitic prejudices,<ref>Black, pg. 39.</ref> and was quoted as stating that Jews "are, probably, the scum of the earth."<ref name="Bl149"/><ref name="DH98">Doherty. pg. 98. *For more discussion of Breen's antisemitism, see Doherty (2009), chapter 10, in the "Further reading" section.</ref> When Breen died in 1965, the trade magazine ''Variety'' stated, "More than any single individual, he shaped the moral stature of the American motion picture."<ref>Doherty, pg. 9.</ref> Although the Legion's impact on the more effective enforcement of the Code is unquestionable, its influence on the general populace is harder to gauge. A study done by Hays after the Code was finally fully implemented found that audiences were doing the exact opposite of what the Legion had recommended. Each time the Legion protested a film it meant increased ticket sales; unsurprisingly, Hays kept these results to himself and they were not revealed until many years later.<ref name="La201">LaSalle, pg. 201.</ref> In contrast to big cities, boycotts in smaller towns were more effective and theater owners complained of the harassment they received when they exhibited salacious films.<ref>Doherty, pp. 324–325.</ref>
Many actors and actresses, such as Edward G. Robinson, Barbara Stanwyck, and Clark Gable, continued their careers apace after the Code was enforced. However, others, such as [[Ruth Chatterton]] (who decamped to England around 1936) and [[Warren William]] (who died relatively young in the 1940s), who excelled during this period, are mostly forgotten today.<ref name="Tu371"/><ref name="vol2"/>
==After the Code era – Motion Picture Association of America film rating system (MPAA)==
[[File:Three on a Match Dvorak Wellman.jpg|thumb|right|Scenes such as this, in which a man is about to kiss a woman in bed in her nightgown, ([[Warren William]] and [[Ann Dvorak]] in 1932's ''[[Three on a Match]]'') were proscribed by the Production Code. After 1934, a scene such as this would not appear in a Hollywood film for decades.]]
Censors like Martin Quigley and Joseph Breen understood that:
<blockquote>a private industry code, strictly enforced, is more effective than government censorship as a means of imposing religious dogma. It is secret, for one thing, operating at the pre-production stage. The audience never knows what has been trimmed, cut, revised, or never written. For another, it is uniform—not subject to hundreds of different licensing standards. Finally and most important, private censorship can be more sweeping in its demands, because it is not bound by constitutional due process or free-expression rules—in general, these apply to only the government—or by the command of church-state separation … there is no question that American cinema today is far freer than in the heyday of the Code, when Joe Breen's blue pencil and the Legion of Decency's ever-present boycott threat combined to assure that films adhered to Catholic Church doctrine.<ref>Heins, Marjorie. [http://www.google.com/search?q=cache:1wufM1hmlzsJ:www.fepproject.org/commentaries/themiracle.html+Martin+Quigley+censor&hl=en&gl=us&ct=clnk&cd=7 "''The Miracle'': Film Censorship and the Entanglement of Church and State"], fepproject.org; accessed October 4, 2010.</ref></blockquote>
Termed by Breen as "Compensating moral value", the maxim was that "any theme must contain at least sufficient good in the story to compensate for, and to counteract, any evil which relates."<ref name="DH11">Doherty, pg. 11.</ref> Hollywood could present evil behavior, but only if it were eradicated by the end of the film, "with the guilty punished, and the sinner redeemed".<ref name="DH11"/>
Pre-Code scholar Thomas Doherty summarized the practical effects:<ref>Doherty, p. 10.</ref>
<blockquote>Even for moral guardians of Breen's dedication, however, film censorship can be a tricky business. Images must be cut, dialogue overdubbed or deleted, and explicit messages and subtle implications excised from what the argot of film criticism calls the "[[diegesis]]". Put simply, the diegesis is the world of the film, the universe inhabited by the characters existing in the landscape of cinema. "Diegetic" elements are experienced by the characters in the film and (vicariously) by the spectator; "nondiegetic" elements are apprehended by the spectator alone.... The job of the motion picture censor is to patrol the diegesis, keeping an eye and ear out for images, languages, and meanings that should be banished from the world of film.... The easiest part of the assignment is to connect the dots and connect what is visually and verbally forbidden by name. … More challenging is the work of the textual analysis and narrative rehabilitation that discerns and redirects hidden lessons and moral meanings.</blockquote>
[[File:Shirleytemple young.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Shirley Temple]], a rising star in 1934, was advertised as "an attraction that will serve as an answer to many of the attacks that are being hurled at pictures."<ref name="DH333">Doherty, p. 333.</ref>]]
The censors thus expanded their jurisdiction from what was seen to what was implied in the spectator's mind. In ''[[The Office Wife (1930 film)|The Office Wife]]'' (1930), several of [[Joan Blondell]]'s disrobing maneuvers were strictly forbidden and the implied image of the actress being naked just off-screen was deemed too suggestive even though it relied upon the audience using their imaginations, so post-Code releases of the film had scenes which were blurred or rendered indistinct, if allowed at all.<ref name="DH11"/>
Following the July 1, 1934 decision by the studios put the power over film censorship in Breen's hands, he appeared in a series of newsreel clips promoting the new order of business, assuring Americans that the motion-picture industry would be cleansed of "the vulgar, the cheap, and the tawdry" and that pictures would be made "vital and wholesome entertainment".<ref>Doherty, pp. 328–30.</ref> All scripts now went through PCA,<ref name="La201"/> and several films playing in theaters were ordered withdrawn.<ref name="Ja106">Jacobs, p. 106.</ref><ref>Doherty, pg. 331.</ref>
The first film Breen censored in the production stage was the Joan Crawford film ''[[Forsaking All Others]]''.<ref>Doherty, pg. 329.</ref> Although Independent film producers vowed they would give "no thought to Mr. Joe Breen or anything he represents", they caved on their stance within one month of making it.<ref name="DH334">Doherty, p. 334.</ref> The major studios still owned most of the successful theaters in the country,<ref name="SS190"/> and studio heads such as [[Harry Cohn]] of [[Columbia Pictures]] had already agreed to stop making indecent films.<ref>[[United Press]]. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IzcyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FOMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1882,689742&dq=will+hays&hl=en Will Hays Confers with Film Leaders], ''Berkeley Daily Gazette'', July 10, 1934; accessed October 20, 2010.</ref><ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19340721.2.151.7 Stir in Hollywood], ''[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]]'', July 21, 1934; accessed October 20, 2010</ref> In several large cities audiences booed when the Production seal appeared before films.<ref name="DH334"/> But the Catholic Church was pleased, and in 1936 [[Pope Pius XI]] stated that the U.S. film industry "has recognized and accepts its responsibility before society."<ref name="ah"/> The Legion condemned zero films produced by the MPPDA between 1936 and 1943.<ref>Corliss essay in Schatz, pg. 151.</ref>
A coincidental upswing in the fortunes of several studios was publicly explained by Code proponents such as the ''Motion Picture Herald'' as proof positive that the code was working.<ref>Doherty, pg. 336.</ref> Another fortunate coincidence for Code supporters was the torrent of famous criminals such as [[John Dillinger]], [[Baby Face Nelson]], and [[Bonnie and Clyde]] that were killed by police shortly after the PCA took power. Corpses of the outlaws were shown in newsreels around the country, alongside clips of [[Al Capone]] and [[Machine Gun Kelly]] in [[Alcatraz Island|Alcatraz]].<ref name="DH339"/> Among the unarguably positive aspects of the Code being enforced was the money it saved studios in having to edit, cut, and alter films to get approval from the various state boards and censors. The money saved was in the millions annually.<ref name="DH335">Doherty, pg. 335.</ref> A spate of more wholesome family films featuring performers such as [[Shirley Temple]] took off.<ref name="DH333"/>
[[File:Leo Gorcey and James Cagney in Angels With Dirty Faces trailer.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|[[Leo Gorcey]] and [[James Cagney]] in ''[[Angels with Dirty Faces]] (1937)]]
Stars such as James Cagney redefined their images. Cagney played a series of patriots, and his gangster in ''[[Angels with Dirty Faces]]'' (1937) purposefully acts like a coward when he is executed so children who had looked up to him would cease any such admiration.<ref name="DH339">Doherty, pg. 339.</ref> Breen in essence neutered Groucho Marx, removing most of his jokes which directly referenced sex, although some sexual references slipped through unnoticed in the Marx Brothers post-Code pictures.<ref>Gardner (1988), pp. 114–116, 118–120.</ref> In the political realm, films such ''[[Mr. Smith Goes to Washington]]'' (1939) in which [[James Stewart]] tries to change the American system from within while reaffirming its core values, stand in stark contrast to ''Gabriel Over the White House'' where a dictator is needed to cure America's woes.<ref>Doherty, pp. 341–342.</ref>
Some pre-Code movies suffered irreparable damage from censorship after 1934. When studios attempted to re-issue films from the 1920s and early 1930s, they were forced to make extensive cuts. Films such as ''[[Mata Hari (1931 film)|Mata Hari]]'' (1931), ''[[Arrowsmith (film)|Arrowsmith]]'' (1931), and ''[[A Farewell to Arms (1932 film)|A Farewell to Arms]]'' (1932) exist only in their censored versions. Many other films survived intact because they were too controversial to be re-released, such as ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1931 film)|The Maltese Falcon]]'' (1931), which was remade a decade later with the same name, and thus never had their master negatives edited.<ref>Vieira, pg. 6.</ref> In the case of ''[[Convention City]]'' (1933), which Breen would not allow to be re-released in any form, the entire film remains missing. Although it has been rumored that all prints and negatives were ordered destroyed by Jack Warner in the late thirties,<ref>Vieira, pp. 211–212, 230</ref> further research shows the negative was in the vaults as late as 1948 when it was junked due to nitrate decomposition.<ref>[http://chiseler.org/post/1562863854/where-is-convention-city-hiding Where is Convention City hiding?], chiseler.org; accessed August 9, 2015.</ref>
==Contemporary screenings== In the 1980s, New York City [[Film Forum]] programmer [[Bruce Goldstein]] held the first film festivals featuring pre-Code films.<ref>LaSalle, Mick. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/mlasalle/detail?entry_id=43388 "Bruce Goldstein Introduces ''The Tingler''"], sfgate.com, July 10, 2009, accessed October 17, 2010.</ref> Goldstein is also credited by San Francisco film critic [[Mick LaSalle]] as the person to bring the term "pre-Code" into general use.<ref name="Gold">LaSalle, Mick. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/mlasalle/detail?entry_id=33857 "A Gift Idea – An Interview With Rialto's Bruce Goldstein"], sfgate.com, December 21, 2008; accessed October 17, 2010.</ref>
[[UCLA]] ran several series of pre-Code films during the 2000s, showcasing films which had not been seen for decades, and not available on any home media.<ref>Turan, Kenneth. [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jan/27/entertainment/ca-precode27 "Back when Hollywood played it fast and sassy"], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 27, 2008, accessed December 28, 2010.</ref>
In 2014 the [[British Film Institute]] ran a 21-film season titled ''Hollywood Babylon: Early Talkies Before the Censors'', at the [[BFI Southbank]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/jon-spira/pre-code-hollywood-the-forgotten-genre_b_5350072.html|title=Pre-Code Hollywood: The Forgotten Genre|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=18 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/classic-movies/10778241/Hollywood-behaving-badly-the-outrageous-films-of-the-early-talkie-era.html|title=Hollywood behaving badly: the outrageous films of the early-talkie era|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=18 April 2017}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox German location |type = Stadtteil |Town = [[Freyburg, Germany|Freyburg]] |image_photo = |image_coa = kein |coordinates = {{coord|51|13|59|N|11|48|0|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |image_plan = |state = Sachsen-Anhalt |district = Burgenlandkreis |elevation = 161 |area = 4.17 |population = 184 |Stand = 2006-12-31 |postal_code = 06632 |area_code = 034464 |licence = BLK |website = [http://www.freyburg-info.de/ www.freyburg-info.de] }} '''Schleberoda''' is a village and a former municipality in the [[Burgenlandkreis]] district, in [[Saxony-Anhalt]], [[Germany]]. Since 1 July 2009, it is part of the town [[Freyburg, Germany|Freyburg]]. It has been proposed by Germany for inscription in the List of [[World Heritage]]. The World Heritage nomination [[Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut]] is representative for the processes that shaped the continent during the [[High Middle Ages]] between 1000 and 1300: [[Christianization]], the so-called [[Landesausbau]] and the dynamics of cultural exchange and transfer characteristic for this very period.{{cite book|title=The Making of Europe: Conquest, Colonization and Cultural Change 950-1350|last=Bartlett|first=Robert|date=1994|publisher=Penguin}} == Description == Schleberoda is located north of the [[Unstrut]]. It was founded as a result of intensive land development by clearance in the [[High Middle Ages]] such as other villages with ″root″ (Roda) in the name (e.g. Albersroda, Baumersorda, Schnellroda, Ebersroda and Schleberoda). The closely bordering local nobles in the area separated their territories using stone landmarks, as is still visible at the historic edges of the nearby woods, authentic landmarks which have been unchanged since the High Middle Ages: The clearance work and founding of new villages ran southwards from the original parish of Mücheln and ended at the Neue Göhle forest, which belonged to the territory of the [[Landgrave of Thuringia|Landgraves of Thuringia]] and could therefore not be cleared.{{cite book|title=Linien und Säume, Zonen und Räume an der Ostgrenze des Reiches im frühen und hohen Mittelalter.|trans-title=Lines and frontiers, zones and spaces at the Eastern border of the empire of the Early and High Medieval Ages|pages=39–56|author=Hardt, Matthias|publisher=Wien|date=2000|language=German}}
The forest Neue Göhle (Old Sorbian name gola = heath forest) has survived as a continuous, large forest complex. It was used for the production of pole wood in the context of [[winegrowing]] at a very early point in time, which is why it had been afforested in the form of coppice-with-standards. Stone landmarks, ditches, banks and paths are still visible at the historic edges of this woods separated the territories of the closely bordering local nobles in the area.{{cite book|date=1913|language=German|trans-title=On the history of the so-called ″circular villages" in the region of Naumburg. An agricultural research.|title=Zur Geschichte der sogenannten "Kreisdörfer" im Naumburger Kreise. Eine agrarhistorische Studie.|author=Naumann, Louis}} [[File:Steinmeister vineyard.jpg|thumb|Steinmeister vineyard]] == Today == Schleberoda has retained the structures and authentic form dating from the time of its foundation. It is an examples of the land development in the contact area between [[Germans]] and [[Slavs]] in the [[High Middle Ages]]. It has been able to retain its original ground plan as a radial round village dating from the High Middle Ages. Around the original village [[pond]], serving for fire-fighting, and the bake house, replaced at the end of the [[18th century]], forward-gabled and side-gabled buildings are grouped, some made with packed loam, with high-quality portals dating from the [[16th century|16th]] to [[19th century]]. The position of the former gate to the compact village settlement is still identifiable today. Including the outer boundary of the official village area is not only identifiable by a circumferential path and has survived in its original form to the north-west in the shape of an impenetrable hedge. The [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] choir tower of the village church with coupled abat sons has survived. == See also == * [[World Heritage Convention]] * [[World Heritage site]] * [[World Heritage Committee]] * [[High Middle Ages]] * [[Cultural landscape|Cultural Landscape]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6FPjj5cWWCg Video of the cultural landscape of Naumburg] [[Category:Villages in Saxony-Anhalt]] [[Category:Cultural heritage of Germany]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:High Middle Ages]] [[Category:Landscape]] [[Category:Saxony-Anhalt]]

The '''siren suit''' is a one-piece garment for the whole body which is easily put on or taken off, originally designed for use on the way to and in [[air-raid shelters]].<ref>URL:http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/siren-suit?q=siren+suit. Accessed: 2013-06-20. (Archived by WebCite® at https://www.webcitation.org/6HViXEs1y)</ref> The suit solved the problems of warmth and modesty encountered when seeking shelter during nighttime [[Strategic bombing|air raids]] in the [[United Kingdom]] during [[World War II]]. It was roomy and could be put on over night clothes quickly when an imminent air raid was announced by the [[siren (noisemaker)|sirens]].
The suit was worn by both children and adults when sheltering in either back garden or public shelters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/ww2peopleswar/stories/69/a2736669.shtml |title=WW2 People's War - My Homemade 'Siren Suit' |publisher=BBC |date=2004-06-12 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref><ref name="tatler">{{cite web|url=http://battleofbritainblog.com/historical-documents/tatler-magazine-summer-1940/ |title=Tatler Magazine, Summer 1940 | Battle of Britain Day by Day |publisher=Battleofbritainblog.com |date= |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Winston Churchill during the Second World War in the United Kingdom H38661.jpg|thumb|Winston Churchill wearing a siren suit beside British Field Marshall [[Bernard Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein|Bernard Montgomery]] during the Second World War in the United Kingdom]]
Similar in style to [[boilersuit]]s worn by many workers including mechanics, brick layers and tank crews to protect their standard clothing, the siren suit was invented by [[Winston Churchill]] as an original leisure suit in the 1930s.<ref name="Reynolds1963">{{cite book|author=Quentin James Reynolds|title=Winston Churchill|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FNgEAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=12 March 2013|date=1 November 1963|publisher=Random House|page=173}}</ref> He played a large part in popularising it as an item of clothing during World War II, wearing it regularly, including when meeting other important people such as U.S. President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], General [[Dwight Eisenhower]]<ref name="Inc1942">{{cite book|author=Time Inc|title=LIFE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C04EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA23|accessdate=11 March 2013|date=19 January 1942|publisher=Time Inc|page=23|issn=0024-3019}}</ref> and Soviet leader [[Joseph Stalin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bJ9aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-E4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4449,5907553|title=Prescott Evening Courier - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref>
The advantages of clothing that could be easily and quickly put on over other clothing led to the adoption of this style of suit during the war by many who were forced to leave their homes to seek shelter during [[strategic bombing|air raids]]. That these raids were announced by the sound of sirens led to the adoption of their name.
==Construction==
Cut loose, with [[zipper]]ed and button closures, a belt and large simple pockets, siren suits were made of many fabrics but most typically wool or other materials available under clothing [[rationing]]. Suits could be bought ready made<ref name="tatler" /><ref name="Veillon2002">{{cite book|author=Dominique Veillon|title=Fashion Under the Occupation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CzZP1Beq2iAC&pg=PA9|accessdate=25 March 2013|date=1 October 2002|publisher=Berg|isbn=978-1-85973-548-0|pages=9–}}</ref> or as a pattern from which they could be hand made with available fabrics.
Some suits had a panel at the back that opened to allow the wearer to use the toilet while still wearing the suit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/IK_JlUpjSfCAqyvCm-nKtw |title=A History of the World – Object : Siren Suit |publisher=BBC |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
==In popular culture==
Winston Churchill was a famous wearer, having a pin stripe version which he wore during the war years and then for portraits by [[Oscar Nemon]] and [[Frank O. Salisbury]] after the war in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite news|author=Vanessa Thorpe and John Vincent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/nov/10/artsandhumanities.politics |title=Churchill's Blitz siren suit put up for auction | UK news | The Observer |publisher=Guardian |date= 11 November 2002|accessdate=2013-06-19 |location=London}}</ref> Another suit, made of bottle-green velvet, was created for him by [[Turnbull & Asser]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG8737053/Turnbull-and-Asser-The-best-of-British.html |title=Turnbull & Asser: The best of British - Telegraph |publisher=Fashion.telegraph.co.uk |date= 2 September 2011|accessdate=2013-06-19 |location=London |first=Luke |last=Leitch}}</ref> One of his gray pinstripe suits was sold in 2002 for £29,875.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bennett |first=Will |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1415948/30000-for-Churchills-suit.html |title=£30,000 for Churchill's suit |publisher=Telegraph |date=2002-12-13 |accessdate=2013-06-19 |location=London}}</ref>
These suits form a common motif in descriptions of war-time childhoods.<ref name="Lynas2010">{{cite book|author=Dick Lynas|title=Pies Were for Thursdays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WJomHm2v_n8C|accessdate=25 March 2013|date=9 June 2010|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-4670-0627-9|page=9}}</ref><ref name="Pearse2011">{{cite book|author=[[Lesley Pearse]]|title=Ellie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PK1F1HM3chsC&pg=PA103|accessdate=25 March 2013|date=30 May 2011|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4464-7443-3|pages=103–}}</ref><ref name="Groves2011">{{cite book|author=Annie Groves|title=Home for Christmas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cO7pJPCtSuIC&pg=PT90|accessdate=25 March 2013|date=27 October 2011|publisher=HarperCollins UK|isbn=978-0-00-741939-5|pages=90–}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

'''Spinlister''' is a website and [[mobile app]] for [[peer-to-peer]] sharing of [[Sports equipment|outdoor sporting gear]], specifically bikes, surf boards, SUPs, skis and snowboards. Bikes are the company’s primary market.<ref name=CBS>{{cite news|title=Bike-share company puts new spin on peer-to-peer rentals|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/spinlister-ride-share-company-puts-new-spin-on-peer-to-peer-rentals/|accessdate=26 August 2015|publisher=CBS News|date=10 January 2015}}</ref> It is commonly referred to as the "[[Airbnb]] for bikes”.<ref name=MikeButcherTC>{{cite web|last1=Butcher|first1=Mike|title=Spinlister Makes It Into Disrupt Battlefield With Its 'Airbnb For Bikes'|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/09/11/spinlister-makes-it-into-disrupt-battlefield-with-its-airbnb-for-bikes/ |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |accessdate=26 Aug 2015}}</ref><ref name="MarianSalzman Forbes">{{cite web|last1=Salzman|first1=Marian|title=Next Year In Business, Innovation And Social Responsibility|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mariansalzman/2014/12/10/next-year-in-business-innovation-and-social-responsibility/|website=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> The platform has listings in 63 countries and users from 120 countries.<ref name=MHurfold_bicycling.com>{{cite web|last1=Hurford|first1=Molly|title=Spinlister Introduces Plan for New Bike Share Model|url=http://www.bicycling.com/bikes-gear/spinlister-introduces-plan-new-bike-share-model/ |publisher=Bicycling.com|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> It was founded in 2011<ref name=MikeButcherTC /> and is headquartered in [[Santa Monica, California]].
==History== The company was founded by Will Dennis and Jeff Noh in May 2011.<ref name=MikeButcherTC /> The idea for Spinlister arose after Dennis listed his own bike for rent on [[Craigslist]] in New York City and saw interest from both locals and tourists to rent it out for more than a few hours.<ref name=JPan_Mashable>{{cite web |last1=Pan |first1=Joann |title=SpinLister Creates Online Hub for Bike Rentals in NYC, SF|url=http://mashable.com/2012/04/02/spinlister-bike-rentals-in-ny-sf/ |publisher=Mashable Inc. |accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref> The company's first two markets were New York City and San Francisco<ref name=MikeButcherTC /><ref name=JBrustein_NYT>{{cite news |last1=Brustein |first1=Joshua|title=There's More Than One Way to Share a Bike|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/19/nyregion/spinlister-and-social-bicycles-develop-bike-sharing-alternatives.html |accessdate=26 August 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 August 2012}}</ref> and started with only bike listings from individuals or existing [[Bike rental|bike rental shops]].<ref name=MikeButcherTC />
Spinlister was the Audience Choice Winner during the [[TechCrunch Disrupt]] Battlefield in San Francisco in 2012.<ref name=MikeButcherTC /> It raised $450,000 in initial funding from investors.<ref name=ASchwartz_fastcoexist>{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Ariel|title=The Return Of Spinlister: How To Revive A Dead Sharing Economy Startup|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1682784/the-return-of-spinlister-how-to-revive-a-dead-sharing-economy-startup |publisher=Fast Company, Inc |accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref>
In late 2012 the company rebranded itself as Liquid and reintroduced itself as a "liquid" marketplace for sharing of assets, including bikes.<ref name=RLawler_TC>{{cite web|last1=Lawler|first1=Ryan|title=Peer-to-Peer Bike-Sharing Startup Spinlister Rebrands As Liquid, Opens Up To All|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/30/strike-spinlister-strike-liquid/ |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> Around this time, the company also moved its headquarters to San Francisco.<ref name=RLawler_TC /> Shortly thereafter, Dennis and Noh shut down the service.
In 2013, the company relaunched under its original name and branding and with a mobile app under the direction of Brazilian entrepreneur and one of the [[Seed money|seed investors]], Marcelo Loureiro.<ref name=ASchwartz_fastcoexist /> The company remains privately funded.<ref name=DLariviere_Forbes>{{cite web|last1=Lariviere|first1=David|title=Global Cycling Sharing Service Spinlister Is Hitting The Ground Running|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidlariviere/2014/05/15/global-cycling-sharing-service-spinlister-is-hitting-the-ground-running/|website=Forbes.com|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref>
==Company== In addition to the website, [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] apps were released in 2013.<ref name=ASchwartz_fastcoexist /><ref name=PSawers_TNW>{{cite web|last1=Sawers|first1=Paul|title=Spinlister takes its ‘Airbnb for bikes’ to Android, and opens up to snowsports rentals too|url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2013/10/04/spinlister-takes-its-airbnb-for-bikes-to-android-and-opens-up-to-snowsports-rentals-too/|website=thenextweb.com|publisher=The Next Web (TNW)|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> The marketplace expanded to include snow and surf equipment in 2013 and 2014, respectively.<ref name=PSawers_TNW /><ref name=OdrMag>{{cite web|title=SUP and Surf Now On Spinlister|url=http://www.odrmag.com/productstechnology/2426-sup-and-surf-now-on-spinlister.html/|website=odrmag.com|publisher=Outdoor Magazine|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2014 and 2015, the company was the official bike share sponsor of the [[Ironman Triathlon]] series.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roethenbaugh|first1=Gary|title=Spinlister supports triathlon with investments in athletes, events and non-profits|url=http://www.triathlonbusiness.com/2015/industry-news/spinlister-supports-triathlon-with-investments-in-athletes-events-and-non-profits/|website=triathlonbusiness.com|accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref>
In March 2015, the company announced the launch of a decentralized bike share model at the [[South by Southwest|South by Southwest music festival]] in [[Austin, Texas]]. The new system does not require a hub or station but rather allows users to locate, book, unlock, ride and relock the bikes through the Spinlister app. The “Smart Bikes” are manufactured by {{ill|VanMoof|nl}} and will be available for existing users to purchase. The first trial market will be held in [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref name=BicycleRetailer>{{cite web|last1=Staff|first1=Brian|title=Spinlister to launch de-centralized bike share program|url=http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2015/03/13/spinlister-launch-de-centralized-bike-share-program#.VdZ-4_nN2oQ/ |publisher=Bicycle Retailer and Industry News |accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=ANewman_bicycletimesmag>{{cite web|last1=Newman|first1=Adam|title=Spinlister unveils new peer-to-peer bike share model|url=http://bicycletimesmag.com/spinlister-unveils-new-peer-to-peer-bike-share-model/ |work=Bicycle Times Magazine |accessdate=26 August 2015}}</ref> {{Update inline|reason=need results of trial date=January 2017|date=January 2017}} In March 2016 the company announced the acquisition of [[Cycleswap]], a Dutch peer-to-peer bike sharing platform.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.rtlz.nl/business/ondernemers/nederlandse-studenten-verkopen-airbnb-voor-fietsen-aan-amerikanen|title = Nederlandse studenten verkopen 'Airbnb voor fietsen' aan Amerikanen |publisher=[[RTL Nieuws]] |access-date = 2016-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cyclingindustry.news/spinlister-acquires-amsterdam-bike-share-business-cycleswap/|title = Spinlister acquires Amsterdam bike share business Cycleswap |publisher = Cycling Industry News |access-date = 2016-04-01}}</ref>
In April 2018, the company announced it will be shutting down on April 22, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://help.spinlister.com/knowledge_base/topics/a-farewell-message-from-spinlister|title=A Farewell Message from Spinlister {{!}} Spinlister Help Center|website=help.spinlister.com|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>

[[Super Robot Chogokin]] |otherlabel1= |otherdata1= |otherlabel2= |otherdata2= |otherlabel3= |otherdata3= }} The {{nihongo|'''Super Sentai Series'''|スーパー戦隊シリーズ|Sūpā Sentai Shirīzu}} is a Japanese [[superhero]] team [[Media franchise#Transmedia franchise|metaseries]] of TV series produced by [[Toei Company]], Toei Agency and [[Bandai]], and aired by [[TV Asahi]] ("[[Sentai]]" is the Japanese word for "task force" or "fighting squadron").{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} The shows are of the ''[[tokusatsu]]'' genre, featuring live action characters and colorful special effects, and are aimed at children. ''Super Sentai'' airs alongside the [[Kamen Rider Series|''Kamen Rider'' series]] in the ''[[Super Hero Time]]'' programming block on Sunday mornings. In North America, the Super Sentai Series is best known as the source material for the ''[[Power Rangers]]'' franchise. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Series overview== {{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}} ===Super Sentai Series=== In every Super Sentai Series, the protagonists are a team of people who – using wrist-worn or hand-held devices – transform into superheroes and gain superpowers – color-coded uniforms, [[signature weapon]]s, sidearms, and fighting skills – to battle a group of evil beings that threaten to take over the Earth. In a typical episode, the heroes thwart the enemies' plans and defeat an army of enemy soldiers and the [[Villain of the week|monster of the week]] before an enlarged version of the monster confronts them, only to be defeated again when the heroes fight it with their [[mecha]]. Each Super Sentai Series is set in its own [[fictional universe]]; various TV, video and film specials feature a team-up between one or more teams. The series was created by [[Shotaro Ishinomori]],{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} then known for the 1971–1973 ''[[Kamen Rider]]'' TV series and the long-running manga ''[[Cyborg 009]]''. He developed the first two Super Sentai Series ''[[Himitsu Sentai Gorenger]]'', which ran from 1975 to 1977, and ''[[J.A.K.Q. Dengekitai]]'', released in 1977. [[Toei Company]] put the franchise on hiatus in 1978,{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} collaborating with [[Marvel Comics]] to produce a live action ''[[Spider-Man (Toei TV series)|Spider-Man]]'' series, which added giant robots to the concept of ''tokusatsu'' shows. The giant robot concept was carried over to Toei and Marvel's next show, ''[[Battle Fever J]]'', released in 1979, and was then used throughout the Super Sentai Series. ===''Power Rangers''=== {{Main|Power Rangers}} In 1993, American production company [[Saban Entertainment]] adapted 1992's ''Kyōryū Sentai Zyuranger'' into ''[[Mighty Morphin Power Rangers]]'' for the [[Fox Kids]] programming block, combining the original Japanese action footage with new footage featuring American actors for the story sequences. Since then, nearly every ''Super Sentai'' series that followed became a new season of ''Power Rangers''.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} Some countries, such as France, Brazil, Thailand, and the Philippines, switched from broadcasting ''Super Sentai'' to ''Power Rangers''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} In 2002, Saban sold the ''Power Rangers'' franchise to [[Disney]]'s [[Buena Vista (brand)|Buena Vista]] division,{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} who owned it until 2010, broadcasting ''Power Rangers'' on [[ABC Kids (United States)|ABC Kids]], [[ABC Family Channel]], [[Jetix]], and [[Toon Disney]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} On 12 May 2010, Saban bought the franchise back from Disney, moving the show to the [[Nickelodeon]] network for 2011.{{cite web|last1=Littleton|first1=Cynthia|title=Saban re-acquires rights to ‘Rangers’|url=https://variety.com/2010/film/news/saban-re-acquires-rights-to-rangers-1118019212/|website=Variety|accessdate=12 May 2010|date=12 May 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418121206/http://variety.com/2010/film/news/saban-re-acquires-rights-to-rangers-1118019212/|archivedate=18 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 1 May 2018, toy company [[Hasbro]] announced they had acquired the ''Power Rangers'' franchise from Saban Capital Group for $522 million.{{cite web|last1=Arrant|first1=Chris|title=SABAN Sells POWER RANGERS for $522 Million|url=https://www.newsarama.com/39721-power-rangers-sold-to-hasbro.html|website=Newsarama|accessdate=May 8, 2018|language=en|date=May 1, 2018}} ===''Power Rangers Dino Force Brave''=== {{Main|Power Rangers Dino Force Brave}} ''Power Rangers Dino Force Brave'' is a 2017 South Korean tokusatsu television show produced by [[Daewon Media]], the same company which distributes the Super Sentai Series in South Korea under the "Power Rangers" label. It serves as a sequel to the 2013 Super Sentai series ''Zyuden Sentai Kyoryuger''. ==Productions== ===Main series=== The following is a list of the Super Sentai Series and their years of broadcast: * ''[[Himitsu Sentai Gorenger]]'' (1975–1977); first series in the franchise and first series to be produced during the [[Shōwa period]]. * ''[[J.A.K.Q.
